Maximum call stack size exceeded!! Too much recursion!!!

You may have seen errors like these when you attempt to run a deeply recursive function. Computers can be so dramatic! But whats the conflict, exactly, between recursion and call stacks? And is there any hope for resolving it into a happy ending? In this musical talk we'll see why recursion poses a problem for our finite-memory call stack, and learn how "Tail Call Optimization" (TCO) lets us get around that problem.

Well sing our way through the meaning of these terms to explore how TCO messes with the call stack (in a useful way!), as we mess with the lyrics to some of our favorite animated musical songs (in a nerdy way!). ","people":[{"name":"Natalia Margolis","twitter":"nsmargolis","pronouns":"she/her"},{"name":"Anjana Vakil","twitter":"AnjanaVakil","pronouns":"she/her"}]}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"TBD","description":"TBD","person":{"name":"Leonardo Zizzamia","twitter":"zizzamia","pronouns":null}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":""}},{"8:30 PM":"Performer TBA"},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Is React Translated Yet?","description":"Over the course of a month, I've had the honor of working with the React team to set up the localization process for their docs. I want to share with you all some of anecdotes from my time on the project. We'll talk cross-cultural foibles, getting sent to GitHub Jail, a frontend dev's futile attempt at bot-building and of course, the importance of localization in making software accessible to all. ","person":{"name":"Nat Alison","twitter":"tesseralis","pronouns":"she/her or they/them"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Job hunting for happiness","description":"A framework for job hunting to maximize happiness. Essentially defining and prioritizing needs/wants, figuring out how to ask quantitative questions to get qualitative answers, and suggestions for follow ups.

I make very deliberate decisions when job hunting and have used this process to great success for the last 6 or so years. I want to share with other people so that they can be happy with new jobs as well! ","person":{"name":"Colleen Briant","twitter":"ccbriant","pronouns":null}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"GitHub":"https://github.com/about/careers/"},{"Medium":"https://medium.com/jobs-at-medium/"},{"Airtable":"https://airtable.com/jobs"}]},{"day":"2019-06-12","schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":""}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":""}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Hexing Ncurses","description":"The first thing programmers learn, Hello World, prints a string to the terminal. But some terminal apps do WAY COOLER things than just printing strings! They move the cursor around the screen, they make colors and animations, and some of them can even take MOUSE INPUT??! How do they even do that??? The answer to this to use lies in mysterious and ancient curses (and includes a brief history of video terminals and the Digital Equipment Corporation). ","person":{"name":"Jeremy Apthorp","twitter":"nornagon","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Hacking Atom Editor","description":"Text editors are complex, perhaps even scary. Writing your own editor extension might sound daunting, but it doesn't have to be! With a livecoding demo, I'll show you just how simple it is to write an extension for Atom Editor. We'll also discuss how to pick starter projects to get up and running with a new language or framework quickly.","person":{"name":"Tilde Ann Thurium","twitter":"annthurium","pronouns":"they/them"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":""}},{"8:30 PM":"Performer TBA"},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"What is the Dojo?","description":"The Dojo is what happens when you combine equal parts martial arts and coding paradigms? Putting those philosophies and practices together into one concept is what makes up Berekely JavaScript Dojo (BJD), and "The dao of the coder". Come see one man struggle to fit heady concepts, like code katas and koans, into a short digestible slide deck. The dao of the coder is to practice patterns. ","person":{"name":"Tre' Grisby","github":"Trewaters","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"HSV, color spaces, and you","description":"TBD ","person":{"name":"Bryan Hughes","twitter":"nebrius","pronouns":null}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Cash bar and open karaoke! Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"GitHub":"https://github.com/about/careers/"},{"Twilio":"https://www.twilio.com/company/jobs"},{"Airtable":"https://airtable.com/jobs"}]},{"day":"2019-05-01","schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":""}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":""}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Publishing Logic","description":"In 2016, a group of friends got together to publish an independent print magazine about technology. Two years, seven issues, one book, and one and a half websites later, I'll share what we've learnedand whether we should've just published it all on the blockchain from the start. ","person":{"name":"Christa Hartsock","twitter":"_hartsick","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"The Art of Training a New Grad","description":"Spring is in the air (well, somewhere), and that means a whole new crop of new grads are about to hit the workplace! Maybe you've extended offers to one or a few, and congratulations! New grads are great! In my past year as a new grad myself, I've seen some wonderful teams train up some wonderful new engineers, designers, product managers, developer advocates, and more! Aaaand I've also seen some missteps along the way. In this talk I'll go through some moves that were great, and some tips I had to learn the hard way, to help you train up your new grad to be happy and healthy at work. Also I really like dogs, so yeah, there's gonna be a lot of pictures of dogs. I'm not sorry. ","person":{"name":"Lexi Galantino","twitter":"_gallexi","pronouns":"she/her or they/them"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":""}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"","title":"Allons, il le faut... Adieu, notre petite table","description":"An aria from _Manon_ by Massenet","person":{"name":"Molly Hanes","twitter":"ebonhawkdown","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Reverse engineering your mouth!","description":"As babies, many of us learn to talk by unconsciously figuring out how to move the muscles in our face. Lets learn to talk again, but this time by looking into whats going on under the hood! Pink Trombone (https://dood.al/pinktrombone/) is a web tool that lets users create sounds by interacting with a virtual oral cavity, nasal cavity, tongue, and throat. Are those building blocks actually enough for speech, and can we teach Pink Trombone to speak English words? What sounds are especially difficult to produce - for humans, and in the app - and why? Join me in digging into the technology behind this app and learning more about how our voices really work. ","person":{"name":"Evy Kassirer","twitter":"evykassirer","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"define.","description":"the projects that have defined my freelancing career and my data visualization styles, and the projects I want to work on going forward.","person":{"name":"Shirley Wu","twitter":"sxywu","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Cash bar and open karaoke! Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"Cloudinary":"https://cloudinary.com/jobs"},{"GitHub":"https://github.com/about/careers/"},{"Twilio":"https://www.twilio.com/company/jobs"}]},{"day":"2019-04-03","schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":""}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":""}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"CoffeeJS - How I hacked a coffee machine with JavaScript","description":"This is the story of how I hacked an API onto my coffee machine. Well look at why I chose JS, what you need to do to take control of a coffee machine, and what other things we can do with JS and hardware. Youll be dreaming of the gadgets in your house that you cant wait to rip open and hack. ","person":{"name":"Dominik Kundel","twitter":"dkundel","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"How to Fail at Accessibility","description":"YOU ARE CURRENTLY ON WEB CONTENT, to enter the web area, press Control-Option-Shift-Down Arrow. If that sounds foreign to you Congratulations! Youve got a whole new world of accessibility to discover! These issues are often invisible to product designers and developers alike, but they dont have to be. Lets break down some of the gotchas and hiccups we faced along the way to overcome any biases we might have in building our JavaScript products.","person":{"name":"Trish Ang","twitter":"feesh","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":""}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"","title":"open ./guitar.mp4 & ","description":"Live guitar performance looped through Ableton Live. [Find Andrew on Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/L1fescape). ","person":{"name":"Andrew Kennedy","twitter":"L1fescape","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Hey, you got C++ in my JavaScript!","description":"For developers who use Node.js, JavaScript is our bread and butter. Occasionally, though, it isnt quite the right tool for the job. Fortunately Node.js provides the ability to load dynamically linked shared objects written in C and C++ these are known as native addons. Lets explore native addons and talk about when and how to use them.","person":{"name":"Michelle Tilley","twitter":"BinaryMuse","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"WebUSB: Making a label printer work in the browser","description":"I learnt how to use WebUSB when I had a task to make label printing easy. I want to share with you what webusb is and how you can use it. I also implemented a printer driver in javascript so that I can print to a label printer directly from the browser. The happy future of easily connecting to custom hardware is close! ","person":{"name":"Kevin Simper","twitter":"kevinsimper","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Let's find out! ","person":{"name":"Ashi Krishnan","twitter":"rakshesha","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"10 Test Smells In 10 Minutes","description":"Ah, those vexing tests that fail once in a while but pass as soon as you re-run them. Don't you hate those things? I *hate* those things. Will a fast-paced listicle-style run-through of causes be helpful? I don't know! Maybe we'll find out! Together! Like a team! Go team!","person":{"name":"Rich Trott","twitter":"trott","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":""}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"","title":"Karaoke!","description":"A rockin' karaoke performance.","person":{"name":"Potch","twitter":"potch","pronouns":null}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Cheers to Maintenance","description":"Sustaining labor might be seen as unglamorous grunt work, but it pays the bills and keeps the lights on. I'll share stories and lessons I've learned on the invaluable work of maintenance. ","person":{"name":"Lydia Kats","twitter":"llkats","pronouns":"she/they"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Decentralized Data Structures","description":"A quick introduction to decentralized data structures and their advantages over centralized and federated data.","person":{"name":"Mikeal Rogers","twitter":"mikeal","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Cash bar and open karaoke! Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"Opendoor":"https://www.opendoor.com/jobs"},{"Storj":"https://storj.io/careers/"},{"GitHub":"https://github.com/about/careers/"}]},{"day":"2019-02-13","mc":{"emoji":"","name":"Laurie Voss","twitter":"seldo","pronouns":"he/him"},"schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":""}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":""}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Offline First: Driving the Downasaur to Extinction ","description":"Networks are flaky, but your app doesnt have to be. From healthcare solutions in the developing world to entertainment for the daily commute, the Offline First approach to web development is transforming user experience. We'll look at how you can use simple tools like PouchDB and CouchDB to build apps that survive and thrive in real-world network conditions. ","person":{"name":"Teri Chadbourne","twitter":"EventTeri","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"A Day In The Life (Of Moving a Couch)","description":"Have you ever wondered why you work harder for gift than a equal cash gift or why it would be awkward to offer to pay for a Christmas dinner. Every day we make many decisions, most of them we are never even conscience of. We will go over what goes through your head when deciding to do something as simple as helping a friend move a couch.","person":{"name":"Mitchell DeMarco","twitter":"neablis12321","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":""}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"","title":"Some nice songs","description":"Liam is a technologist who used to be a street musician. He'll play you some songs he wrote, and some he didn't. He hopes you like them. ","person":{"name":"Liam Campbell","twitter":"liamdanger","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Private class fields in JavaScript","description":"JavaScript is getting the ability to create truly [private fields](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2018/12/class-fields) in classes with a new hashbang syntax. I'd like to share how this proposal evolved in TC39 with the various design and implementation trade-offs. ","person":{"name":"Sathya Gunasekaran","twitter":"_gsathya","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Building a Truly Decentralized Web","description":"With the advent of Bitcoin and Ethereum, developers have been creating decentralized applications that do not depend on a server. Not only can we do away with central databases, but we an also create applications that don't use CDNs. In this talk we will learn how to serve assets in a distributed fashion using IPFS, and why every web developer should consider weaning themselves away from CDNs. ","person":{"name":"Portia Burton","twitter":"pkafei","pronouns":"she/it"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Cash bar and open karaoke! Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"Opendoor":"https://www.opendoor.com/jobs"},{"GitHub":"https://github.com/about/careers/"}]},{"day":"2019-01-09","mc":{"name":"Christian Schlenker","twitter":"wordofchristian","pronouns":null,"emoji":""},"schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":""}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":""}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"SWE through a Puzzlin' Lens","description":"Crossword puzzles might not seem like a pastime you associate with anyone younger than baby boomers, but it turns out that the patterns behind these wonderfully nerdy puzzles are a great lens through which to consider different approaches to software engineering. In this talk, I'll take you on a journey through some of my favorite clues and puzzles, and how they informed and improved my perspectives as a developer. ","person":{"name":"Shelley Vohr","twitter":"codebytere","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Talk to Me NICE: The IndieWeb, Fediverse and You","description":"We spend lots of time working on tools and platforms that optimize for data crunching and extracting value from anything we do online. There's communities that aim to federate our social interactions and bring back the part of the Web that made social networking exciting. As a developer, I'd like to share some thoughts as to how and why I did this and why I'd want you to join as well. ","person":{"name":"Jacky Alcin","twitter":"jackyalcine","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":""}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"","title":"Karaoke!","description":"A rockin' karaoke performance.","person":{"name":"Potch","twitter":"potch","pronouns":null}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"In the Palm of Your Hand: Using Storytelling to Grab Your Reader's Attention","description":"Need your conference proposal to stand out? Want to create memorable blogposts? One of the quickest ways to create an emotional connection with another person is through storytelling. Together, we'll explore how to use words as the connective glue between you and your reader.","person":{"name":"Mimi Nguyen","twitter":"Mimi_Dumpling","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"","title":"Making Waffles: An Intro to the PICO-8 Fantasy Console ","description":"PICO-8 is a game creation tool created by [@lexaloffle](https://twitter.com/lexaloffle), which bills itself as a "fantasy console". This talk will underline the philosophy behind the "fantasy console" concept, and explain how PICO-8 enables the writing of fun, little programs that you can enjoy in your free time. ","person":{"name":"Jason Tu","twitter":"nucleartide","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. "It didn't bother me." Problem dismissed. "Works for me" is a natural reaction when confronted with cultural issues that don't impact us directly. VISNU
